commentary.a: I vanlig användning (både före och efter pu), är "a" och "kin" separata ord, var och en med sin egen mening. I pu betraktas de som synonymer.
commentary.akesi: akesi brukade betyda "ogulligt djur", och definieras på detta sätt i pu, men den definitionen föll ur bruk och togs senare bort i pu-kommentarerna som publicerades med ku.
commentary.alasa: I vissa sammanhang är användningen av "alasa" som ett förverb i betydelsen "att försöka" lika stor eller till och med större än "lukin". I pu har bara "lukin"/"oko" den betydelsen.
commentary.ale:
"ali" är ett alternativ till "ale", myntat i en enkät 2002 för att undvika förvirring med "ala". Användningen av "ale" i stället för "ali" är dock fortfarande vanligare.
Majoriteten av talarna säger att de inte förstår "riklig, överflödig" innebörden, åtminstone utan sammanhang.
"20, 120" var icke-pu betydelser som tidigare användes tillsammans med 100; de är praktiskt taget okända nuförtiden.
commentary.ali: "ali" is an alternative to "ale", coined in a poll in 2002 in order to avoid confusion with "ala". However, the usage of "ale" over "ali" has been more common since at least the release of pu. Generally not considered a word in its own right.
commentary.anpa: In common usage (both before and after pu), "anpa" has the meaning of "place that is down". In pu, "noka" has that meaning instead.
commentary.anu: The usage of "anu" as a content word meaning "choose" remains controversial.
commentary.apeja: According to jan Sonja, "apeja" never appeared in any pre-pu toki pona dictionary made by her and never promoted by her, instead it may have been "just an experimental idea in a forum post".
commentary.en: There are various analyses of the syntactic role of "en". Originally intended to be used as "and", it was changed (via poll in 2002) to just be used with "head nouns". One of the more recent analyses (including 2021's April Fools) treats "en" as a subject marker.
commentary.esun: According to jan Sonja, "esun was told [to her] by a taxi driver who spoke a language from the Akan family in West Africa".
commentary.jan: There are two sides to the concept, "sentient entity" and "homo sapiens", which matters for whether to use the word in edge cases (i.e. aliens, humans turned into werewolves, etc). Which sense is more central to the word remains controversial.
commentary.jelo: Some extend "jelo" to include lime green, but this usage is uncommon.
commentary.jonke: Coined in reference to the Untitled Goose Game fandom.
commentary.kamalawala: The word is from a story called "jan pi Kamalawala". A character's name is described as "nimi Jan pi Kama e Lawa Ala", and a shortened version given as "nimi Kamalawala". jan Kipo is responsible for it becoming a word instead of just a name.
commentary.kepeken: Whether "kepeken" should be used with or without "e" in a predicative position (meaning "to use") remains controversial.
commentary.kijetesantakalu: Coined as an April Fools joke in 2009.
commentary.kiki: The word is loaned from the 2001 Vilanyur S Ramachandran & Edward Hubbard version of Wolfgang Köhler's 1912 psycholinguistic experiment. The experiment studied sound symbolism on the words "bouba" and "kiki".
commentary.kili: In post-ku 2021, metaphorical definitions for kili have been suggested, including but not limited to "offspring" and "product", and are moderately popular. It is not yet clear whether this will remain in use long-term.
commentary.kin:
In common usage (both before and after pu), "a" and "kin" are separate words, each with their own meaning. In pu, they are considered synonyms.
Underwent significant changes in usage in 2002, alongside "en" and (now obsolete) "kan".
commentary.kiwen: This word was coined in a poll in 2002, replacing the compound phrase "wawa ma".
commentary.ko: The "clinging form" definition was elaborated to mean "a shape or mass that sticks or clings; a clot, a thick or viscous lump, a clump that can be reshaped".
commentary.kokosila: In Esperanto, "krokodili" means "to speak among Esperantists in a language besides Esperanto," and is an established bit of Esperanto culture.
commentary.konwe:
Conway hänvisar till John Horton Conway, skapare av den cellulära automatan Game of Life.
"konwe"s avsedda betydelse sträcker sig bortom bara "levande" och "liv". Den kan användas för att beskriva stenar eller floder eller andra icke-levande saker
commentary.ku: Se den officiella Toki Pona-hemsidan för sätt att köpa boken.
commentary.kule: in addition to its pu-definitions, kule is sometimes used to talk about more general kinds of categories, like type, kind, flavour, gender, etc.
commentary.lukin: In common usage (both before and after pu), "lukin" and "oko" are separate words, each with their own meaning. In pu, they are considered synonyms. Those who consider them synonyms typically don't use "oko" at all, preferring "lukin" in all circumstances. The usage of "alasa" as a preverb meaning "try to" is more common than "lukin". In pu, only "lukin" has this meaning. A very common beginner mistake is treating "lukin" as if it means "appearance", due to the mistakenly equating the "visual" meaning as in "pona lukin (visually good)" to mean "looks good".
commentary.misikeke: The word was used privately by jan Sonja up until November 2019, when she mentioned it in the ma pona pi toki pona discord server as a word she was experimenting with. It is believed the word was originally coined in 2007-2009 alongside pan, esun, apeja, monsuta, and pu, but this cannot be proven.
commentary.namako: In common usage (both before and after pu), "sin" and "namako" are separate words, each with their own meaning. In pu, they are considered synonyms. Those who consider them synonyms typically don't use "namako" at all, preferring "sin" in all circumstances.
commentary.nimisin: Mostly used in conversations in English. Likely was popularised by the :nimisin: emote in ma pona, which was originally used to notify Atawan (maintainer of "nimi ale") about newly coined words. In common speech, the meaning got extended to include most or all non-pu words, regardless if they were coined recently or not.
commentary.noka: noka can also mean any action involving the foot or leg, e.g. to kick, to step on, to touch with the leg.
commentary.oko: In common usage (both before and after pu), "lukin" and "oko" are separate words, each with their own meaning. In pu, they are considered synonyms. Those who consider them synonyms typically don't use "oko" at all, preferring "lukin" in all circumstances, though some speakers do the opposite and use "oko" exclusively instead.
commentary.olin: In english, "love" can be used to mean "like a lot", but in toki pona, "olin" doesn't work that way. It indicates an emotional connection or bond, not preference
commentary.omekapo: Coined by jan Maliku in reference to the message "o moku e kala pona", which jan Sonja wrote on their copy of Toki Pona: The Language of Good during a Texas meetup.
commentary.ona: This word was coined in a poll in 2002. It replaced "iki", which was deemed too similar-sounding to "ike". Other options in the poll included "ipi" and "i".
commentary.open: Some proficient speakers use open as a preverb that means "start to," that goes along with the complimentary pini preverb "to stop"
commentary.penpo: Myntad med hänvisning till ma pona pi toki ponas "tenpo pi toki pona taso"-event, och förkortat till "tenpo penpo".
commentary.pi: The usage of "pi" to mean "of" (marking a possessor) is heavily discouraged nowadays, preferring it to only be used for regrouping within phrases.
commentary.pini: Some proficient speakers use pini as a preverb that means "to stop," that goes along with the complimentary open preverb "start to"
commentary.poki: poki is sometimes used as "category" or to express types of things. One example is roles or groups, in discord chat contexts
commentary.pu: Se den officiella Toki Pona-hemsidan för sätt att köpa boken.
commentary.san:
More popular than the synonymous (and older) tuli.
san was also part of a set of 10 digit words created by jan Lenoka: lenke, jatu, ini, san, se, nun, loku, take, patu, kajo (0 through 9). All of these coinages except for san lack notability to be included in the main dictionary. They can be found in the sandbox.
commentary.seli: In pu, definitions of seli are described as adjectives. ku's pu corrections clarify that these refer to nouns instead.
commentary.sin: In common usage (both before and after pu), "sin" and "namako" are separate words, each with their own meaning. In pu, they are considered synonyms. Those who consider them synonyms typically don't use "namako" at all, preferring "sin" in all circumstances.
commentary.su: This word was originally coined in ku as a reserved word for jan Sonja's future use. It was redefined upon the release of the first su book, making its status as a ku word debatable.
commentary.sutopatikuna: Coined by Alexandre Baudry in 2009 in response to jan Sonja coining "kijetesantakalu" as part of 2009's April Fools.
commentary.taso: Some proficient speakers use taso as a connector between sentences (X taso Y), similar to "X, but Y," as though taso behaved like la grammatically.
commentary.te: May be paired with "to", or used on its own. It is unclear how accepted either approach is among te / to users.
commentary.to: May be paired with "te", or used on its own. It is unclear how accepted either approach is among te / to users.
commentary.tonsi:
* - Broader in meaning, somewhat less commonly accepted.
Widely regarded in the community to be a crucial addition to toki pona. Occasionally referred to as an "honorary pu word" to highlight its status, or equated to a pu word outright.
commentary.unpa: Also defined as "have marital relations with" in pu; removed due to potential confusion.
commentary.usawi: Originally, usawi also included "technology so complex it's impossible to tell apart from magic" in its meaning, but this meaning has been deprecated by the creator.
commentary.uta: The dot in the "uta" sitelen pona is to distinguish luka-uta from moku.
commentary.wa: Ses ibland som en variant av "a".
commentary.wasoweli: First used as the name for a species in a mod for Caves of Qud created by akesi kon Nalasuni. Later appeared in ku as exclusively part of a translation for "penguin".
commentary.wuwojiti: May be seen not as a word in toki pona, but as a kind of memorisation tool in English to refer to the "banned" syllables. Occasionally extended to wuwojitinmanna to include the illegal consecutive nasal consonants.
commentary.yupekosi: Coined as a random keystroke. It is presumed jan Sonja used "y" by mistake, but then made it part of the joke by adding "nobody knows how to pronounce the y".

definitions.a: (interjektion) aha, oh, ha, öh, eh, oj; (partikel) [kommer efter något för betoning eller som känsla]
definitions.akesi: reptil, groddjur, djur med fjäll, djur som kryper
definitions.ala: inte, inget, nej; (partikel) [negerar ett ord eller en fras]; (partikel) [bildar en ja-eller-nejfråga]; (siffra) noll
definitions.alasa: jaga, plocka (bär, svamp, etc.), samla, leta efter, försök; (pv.) att försöka
definitions.ale: allt, alla, varje, helhet, universum; (siffra) ett hundra
definitions.anpa: botten, undersida; under, nedanför; besegrad, ödmjuk, lågmäld
definitions.ante: annorlunda, förändrad; ändra, förändra, modifiera; annan, skillnad
definitions.anu: (partikel) [separerar flera möjligheter, ersätter en annan partikel], eller
definitions.apeja: skuld, skam, undvika, stigma; att anklaga, att peka ut, att avslöja, att vanära, att genera
definitions.awen: stanna, vänta, pausa; skydda, beskydda; fortsätta; (pv.) att fortsätta
definitions.esun: handel, byteshandel, utbyte, köpa, sälja; marknad, affär, mässa, basar, affärsplats
definitions.ijo: sak, ting, objekt, enhet, varelse, materia, fenomen
definitions.ike: av negativ kvalitet, t.ex. dålig, obehaglig, skadlig, onödig
definitions.insa: insida, center, mellan, mitt, mittpunkt, intern, inre
definitions.isipin: att tänka, brainstorma, rationalisera, dra slutsats, fundera
definitions.jaki: äckligt, orent, ohygieniskt, giftigt, motbjudante, ruttet
definitions.jami: mums; framkalla eller stimulera en positiv sensorisk upplevelse
definitions.kala: fisk, marint djur, havsdjur, simmande varelser
definitions.kalama: Att ge ifrån sig ljud; ljud, t.ex. sjunga, åska, trumma, klappa, skratta, pip
definitions.kama: arriving, coming, future, summoned; (preverb) to become, manage to, succeed in
definitions.ken: kan, får, förmåga, tillåtelse; möjlighet, kanske; tillåta, göra möjlig; (pv.) att kunna
definitions.kijetesantakalu: tvättbjörn, veckelbjörn (kinkajou); något djur i familjen Halvbjörnar (Procyonidae); något djur i överfamiljen Musteloidea
definitions.kin: (particle) [after phrase or at sentence start] too, also, as well, additionally
definitions.kipisi: split, cut, slice; piece, part; sharp, pointy
definitions.kiwen: hard object e.g. metal, stone, wood
definitions.ko: semi-solid, e.g. paste, powder, goo, sand, soil, clay; squishy, moldable; sticky
definitions.kokosila: att prata något annat språk än Toki Pona i ett sammanhang där Toki Pona hade varit mer lämpligt
definitions.kon: air, breath, wind; essence, spirit, soul, ghost; unseen agent
definitions.konwe: animacitet, liv; autonom varelse, levande ting, organism; levande, dynamisk; att ge liv åt, att väcka liv i
definitions.ku: interacting with the book Toki Pona Dictionary (2021) by Sonja Lang
definitions.kule: color, pigment; category, genre, flavor; colorful, diverse
definitions.kulijo: (interjection) [casually express appreciation or acknowledgement]; cool, fine, okay
definitions.kulupu: group, community, society, company, nation, collection, team, crowd
definitions.kute: ear, hearing organ; hear, listen, pay attention to, obey
definitions.la: (particle) [mark the previous statement as context to the following statement]
definitions.lape: sleep, rest, break from an activity or work
definitions.laso: turquoise, blue, green, cyan, indigo, lime green
definitions.lawa: head, mind, brain; control, lead, guide; government, leader; rule, law
definitions.leko: square, cube, block, blocky object e.g. bricks, stairs
definitions.len: cloth, clothing, fabric, textile; covered, hidden, secret, private
definitions.lete: cold, cool, frozen; freeze, chill; raw, uncooked
definitions.li: (particle) [marks the start of an indicative verb (statement)]
definitions.lili: small, short, young; few; piece, part
definitions.linja: long, flexible thing, e.g. rope, yarn, hair, fur, line, strand
definitions.linluwi: bonded things which are stronger through their bonds e.g. network, internet, connection; weave, braid, interlace
definitions.lipu: flat and bendable object, e.g. paper, card, leaf; written text or document, e.g. book, website, clay tablet
definitions.loje: red, magenta, scarlet, pink, rust-colored, reddish orange
definitions.lon: present, existing, real, true; (preposition) located at, in, during, in the context of
definitions.luka: hand, arm, tactile limb, grasping limb; to grasp, interact with, feel using touch; (number) five
definitions.lukin: see, look, view, examine, read, watch; visual; eye, seeing organ; (preverb) try to
definitions.lupa: hole, pit, cave, doorway, window, portal
definitions.ma: earth, land, soil; country, territory, world; outdoors
definitions.mama: parent, ancestor; creator, originator; caretaker, sustainer, guardian
definitions.mani: money, currency; thing of value e.g. gold, investment, livestock
definitions.meli: woman, female, feminine person, wife, girlfriend
definitions.meso: medelpunkt, medium, medioker, medelmåttig; varken det ena eller det andra
definitions.mije: man, male, masculine person, husband, boyfriend
definitions.misa: gruppen Glires (gnagare och hardjur) eller Eulipotyphla (äkta insektsätare); råtta, mus, ekorre, kanin, gnagare {~ suli} kapybara
definitions.misikeke: medical item or practice e.g. prescriptions, meditation, exercise, bandages, therapy
definitions.moku: eat, drink, consume, swallow, ingest; food, edible thing
definitions.moli: death, dead, die, dying; kill, murder
definitions.monsuta: fear, nervousness, dread; scary, frightening; scary thing e.g. predator, threat, danger
definitions.mun: moon, night sky object, star, celestial body
definitions.musi: fun, game, entertainment, art, play, amusing, interesting, comical, silly
definitions.n: (interjection) hm, uh, mm, er, umm, [indicate thinking or pause]
definitions.nasa: strange, unusual, silly, abnormal, unexpected; drunk, intoxicated
definitions.nasin: method, doctrine, tradition; path, road, way
definitions.nena: protuberances e.g. bump, button, hill, nose
definitions.nimisin: alla icke-pu ord; alla nya ord; alla skämtord
definitions.noka: foot, leg, organ of locomotion, roots
definitions.o: (particle) [marks the end of a vocative (who is being spoken to)], [marks the start of an imperative (command, wish, instruction)], should
definitions.ojuta: adaptation of the English meme "ligma", (literally) "o uta" (lick)
definitions.oko: see, look, view, examine, read, watch; visual; eye, seeing organ; (preverb) try to
definitions.olin: to have a strong emotional bond with, e.g. affection, appreciation, compassion, respect; platonic, romantic, or familial relationships
definitions.omekapo: goodbye, farewell, see you later, (literally) "o moku e kala pona" (eat a good fish)
definitions.open: begin, start, open, turn on; beginning
definitions.owe: totalitarian, Orwellian; of or relating to Big Brother from the book Ninety Eighty-Four
definitions.pakala: damaged, broken, botched, harmed, messed up; mistake
definitions.pake: stoppa, avbryta; att blockera; att förhindra
definitions.pali: work, activity; create, build, design; put effort toward, take action on
definitions.palisa: long and hard thing e.g. branch, pole, rod, stick, spine, mast
definitions.pan: grains, starchy foods, baked goods e.g. rice, sorghum, bread, noodles, masa, porridge, injera
definitions.pana: att ge, skicka, avge, förse, ställa, släppa
definitions.pi: (particle) [group the following words into one modifier for the previous word]
definitions.pika: elektrisk, elektronisk, ledande, mekanisk, online; elektricitet, blixt, åska, nätverk
definitions.pilin: experience e.g. emotion, feeling, touch; heart (physical or emotional)
definitions.pimeja: dark, unlit; dark color, e.g. black, purple, brown
definitions.pini: finish, stop, prevent; close, disable, turn off; ended, past; edge, end, conclusion
definitions.pipi: insect, bug, spider, tiny crawling creature
definitions.poka: hip, side; next to, nearby, vicinity
definitions.poki: container e.g. bag, bowl, box, cup, cupboard, drawer, folder
definitions.pona: positive quality, e.g. good, pleasant, helpful, friendly, useful, peaceful
definitions.pu: interacting with the book Toki Pona: The Language of Good by Sonja Lang
definitions.puwa: fluffig, mjuk (något som kan bli ihoptryckt och kommer försöka återgå till sin ursprungliga form)
definitions.sama: same, similar, alike; (adjective) peer, fellow, each other; (preposition) similar to, same as
definitions.seli: hot, warm; heat, fire, flame; burn
definitions.selo: outer layer, e.g. skin, peel, shell, bark; outer shape, outer form, boundary
definitions.seme: (particle) [indicate a question by marking missing info in a sentence]; what, which, who
definitions.sewi: up, top, above, highest part; divine, sacred, supernatural; awesome, inspiring, excelling
definitions.sijelo: body, shape, physical state, torso, substance, form
definitions.sike: circle, sphere, spiral, round thing e.g. ball, wheel; repeating thing e.g. cycle, orbit, loop
definitions.sin: new, fresh, update; repeat, do again
definitions.sinpin: vertical surface e.g. wall, board; front of something e.g. face
definitions.sitelen: bild, fotografi, avbildning, symbol, tecken, skrift
definitions.sona: knowledge, information, data; know, be skilled in, be wise about; (preverb) know how to
definitions.su: interagera med en bok ur Sonja Langs illustrerade bokserie, som började med Trollkarlen från Oz
definitions.suli: big, heavy, large, long, tall, wide; important, relevant
definitions.suno: light, shine, glow, radiance; sun, light source; brightness
definitions.supa: flat horizontal surface, especially to put or rest things on e.g. bed, floor, desk, plate, table, platform, stage
definitions.taki: klibbigt, magnetiskt; förbindelse, attrahera, fästa, gem
definitions.taso: only, exclusively; (particle) [marks a sentence as qualifying or contradictory], but, however
definitions.tawa: motion, e.g. walking, shaking, flight, travel; (preposition) to, for, going to, from the perspective of
definitions.telo: liquids e.g. water, gasoline, soda, lava, soup, oil, ink
definitions.tenpo: tid, händelse, situation, tillfälle, period, varaktighet
definitions.toki: communicate, say, think; conversation, story; language
definitions.tomo: indoor space or shelter e.g. room, building, home, tent, shack
definitions.usawi: magi, häxkonst, trolldom; förtrollad, magisk, övernaturlig, ockult, oförståligt
definitions.utala: kämpa, tävla, strida; tävling, utmaning; kamp, strävan
definitions.wan: (siffra) ett; singular; kombinera, sammanfoga, blanda, smälta samman
definitions.wasoweli: djur med egenskaper av både waso och soweli
definitions.wawa: kraft, energi, styrka; självsäker, intensiv, kraftfull; fantastisk, imponerande
definitions.weka: frånvarande, borta, avlägsen; ta bort, bli av med
definitions.wekama: lämna och komma tillbaka, vara temporärt frånvarande med avsikten att återvända
definitions.wuwojiti: att använda en eller fler av de förbjudna stavelserna wu, wo, ji eller ti; att bryta mot Toki Ponas fonotax
definitions.yupekosi: att uppföra sig som George Lucas och revidera dina gamla kreativa verk och faktiskt göra dem sämre

awen.definition: keep, care for, hold (in a particular state)

kama.definition: event, arrive, happen, become, bring about, summon

kamalawala.definition: 'arrival of no government', the beginning of anarchy

kokosila.definition: to speak among Esperantists in a language other than Esperanto

konwe.definition: John Conway, creator of The Game of Life

omekapo.definition: 'eat a good fish', wishing somebody well

pu.definition: unworked wood, sincere, honest, inherent quality, simple

taki.definition: the sound of two magnets hitting each other (onomatopoeia)

sp_etymology.a: exclamation radical + Latin lowercase letter A; radical from exclamation point (!), without the full stop at the bottom. compare o
sp_etymology.akesi: animal radical; pictogram of a lizard. radical represents eyes
sp_etymology.ala: X mark, a crosslinguistic symbol for negation
sp_etymology.alasa: pictogram of a bow and an arrow
sp_etymology.anpa: location radical + "container"; the latter perhaps from a truncated square for a general object (compare sinpin) or a container (compare poki). for the radical, see also how dots are used in blissymbols; compare blissymbol "below"
sp_etymology.ante: perhaps alteration from sama, or a combination of sama and ala. perhaps an ideogram representing a diversion of two lines
sp_etymology.awen: motion radical; legs facing against each other, implying standing
sp_etymology.esun: not from a currency symbol (sonja confirmed; said “i think that one is from Mikmaq” but couldn't find a mikmaq symbol similar to it).
sp_etymology.ijo: a circle, for a general object
sp_etymology.ike: pictogram of a frowning mouth. compare pona
sp_etymology.ilo: perhaps a pictogram of a hammer
sp_etymology.jan: head radical; pictogram of a person showing the shoulders
sp_etymology.jo: perhaps a pictogram of a person pointing at themself or holding something
sp_etymology.kama: motion radical; legs facing to the left. compare tawa and blissymbol “walk”
sp_etymology.kijetesantakalu: a drawing of a raccoon with a tail
sp_etymology.kili: pictogram of a fruit, perhaps an apple
sp_etymology.kiwen: pictogram of a rock or a gem
sp_etymology.kon: ideogram; wavy lines to indicate the fluidity of gas. compare telo
sp_etymology.konwe: pictogram of a glider in Conway's Game of Life, a machine which moves across the game board.
sp_etymology.ku: pictogram of the front cover of “Toki Pona Dictionary”, depicting a jacket with a toki pona patch.
sp_etymology.kule: color radical; perhaps the horizontal line indicates the sense of “the concept itself”. or perhaps a pictogram of light passing through a prism (color radical)
sp_etymology.kulupu: pictogram of a group consisting of three members represented by circles
sp_etymology.kute: pictogram of an ear. compare blissymbol “ear”
sp_etymology.la: perhaps related to blissymbol “later” and “ago”, or perhaps a parenthesis
sp_etymology.lawa: head radical; perhaps the horizontal line for the same reason as in kule. alternatively perhaps a pictogram of a person wearing a cap
sp_etymology.len: perhaps a pictogram of a piece of fabric
sp_etymology.lili: ideogram showing smaller size compared to suli
sp_etymology.lipu: pictogram of a sheet of paper. compare blissymbol “paper”
sp_etymology.lon: location radical above a line. compare blissymbol “over”
sp_etymology.lukin: pictogram of an eye. compare blissymbol “eye”
sp_etymology.lupa: pictogram of a concave surface. compare nena
sp_etymology.mama: head radical; perhaps the smaller circle representing the child
sp_etymology.mani: a pictogram of a large domestic animal, such as a cow (sonja confirmed)
sp_etymology.mi: perhaps a hand pointing towards the speaker. compare sina and ona
sp_etymology.mije: head radical with perhaps wide shoulders. compare jan
sp_etymology.moli: head radical; a dead person, represented by the crossed eyes
sp_etymology.monsuta: visual representation of shaking as seen in cartoons
sp_etymology.mun: pictogram of a crescent moon. compare blissymbol “moon”
sp_etymology.musi: perhaps a pictogram of a smile with rosy cheeks or a lyre
sp_etymology.mute: ideogram consisting of three tally marks. compare wan and tu
sp_etymology.n: exclamation radical with the lowercase letter “n”
sp_etymology.nasa: perhaps spiral representing “dizziness”, as can be commonly seen in Japanese manga and anime
sp_etymology.nasin: ideogram consisting of an arrow along a vertical line
sp_etymology.nena: pictogram of a convex surface. compare lupa
sp_etymology.nimi: perhaps a pictogram of a nametag or sitelen pona cartouche
sp_etymology.noka: pictogram of a foot with an ankle
sp_etymology.o: exclamation radical + Latin lowercase letter O. compare a
sp_etymology.olin: two heart symbols (♡), perhaps to distinguish from pilin. [alternate] pilin with emitters
sp_etymology.ona: perhaps a hand pointing sideways. compare mi and sina
sp_etymology.open: perhaps a pictogram of an opened container
sp_etymology.pan: perhaps a pictogram of a grain crop
sp_etymology.pimeja: color radical; perhaps the cross representing the absence of light
sp_etymology.pipi: animal radical; pictogram of a bug
sp_etymology.pona: pictogram of a smiling mouth. compare ike
sp_etymology.pu: pictogram of the cover of the book “Toki Pona: The Language of Good”. alternatively a semantic compound glyph of lipu and toki pona
sp_etymology.seli: perhaps a pictogram of a lit campfire or a simplified pictogram of a fire
sp_etymology.sijelo: perhaps a pictogram of a torso
sp_etymology.sike: two circles, perhaps to distinguish from ijo. alternatively outline of a thick empty circle
sp_etymology.sina: perhaps a hand pointing towards the listener. compare mi and ona
sp_etymology.sitelen: perhaps a representation of symbols on a piece of paper (lipu)
sp_etymology.soweli: animal radical; pictogram of a mammal
sp_etymology.su: pictogram of the front cover of The Wizard of Oz illustrated story book, depicting the yellow brick road from the story
sp_etymology.suli: ideogram showing bigger size compared to lili
sp_etymology.supa: pictogram of a table. compare blissymbol “table”
sp_etymology.suwi: perhaps a pictogram of a smiling face
sp_etymology.tan: a leaping arrow pointing from right to left, implying derivation or cause
sp_etymology.tawa: motion radical; legs facing to the right. compare kama and blissymbol “walk”
sp_etymology.tenpo: piktogram av en klocka. jämför blissymbolen för "tid"
sp_etymology.toki: emitters + ijo or a general circle
sp_etymology.tomo: pictogram of a house. compare blissymbol “house”
sp_etymology.tu: two tally marks. compare mute and wan
sp_etymology.unpa: perhaps a derivation of heart symbol (especially visible from the original drawing of the character), or a knot pattern implying intercourse, or perhaps a pictogram of a genitalia
sp_etymology.walo: color radical; perhaps the reverse of pimeja, the color radical cutting of the cross instead of vice versa
sp_etymology.wan: one tally mark or Indo-Arabic numeral 1, perhaps to make it more distinct
sp_etymology.waso: animal radical; pictogram of a bird
sp_etymology.wawa: perhaps a pictogram of a person with raised arms, to signify strength
sp_etymology.weka: “poof lines”; indicating the movement of something disappearing
